verses.text: After these things, when the anger of King Ahasuerus had subsided, he remembered Vashti, what she had done, and what was decreed against her.
verses.comment: The king’s memory of Vashti shows the consequences of his earlier decree, establishing the principle of royal authority prevailing even over personal attachment.

verses.text: Then the king’s young attendants, who served him, said, 'Let beautiful young virgins be sought for the king.'
verses.comment: The attendants take initiative, showing how God can work even through secular authorities and their plans (cf. Prov. 21:1).

verses.text: And let the king appoint officers in all the provinces of his kingdom to gather every beautiful young virgin to the citadel of Susa, into the harem, under the custody of Hegai, the king’s eunuch, keeper of the women; and let ointments be given to them.
verses.comment: The centralizing of candidates for queen shows the vastness of the kingdom and sets up Esther’s introduction, emphasizing providence over coincidence.

verses.text: And let the young woman who pleases the king be queen instead of Vashti.' This pleased the king, and he did so.
verses.comment: This verse sets the stage for the selection process, prefiguring how divine favor brings elevation (cf. Ps. 75:6–7).

verses.text: Now there was a Jew in Susa the citadel, whose name was Mordecai, the son of Jair, son of Shimei, son of Kish, a Benjaminite,
verses.comment: Mordecai’s genealogy connects him to King Saul’s line (cf. 1 Sam. 9:1), echoing the tension with Haman (descendant of Agag).

verses.text: who had been carried away from Jerusalem among the exiles, when King Jeconiah of Judah was taken into exile by Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon.
verses.comment: This highlights the context of exile, a recurring biblical theme of God’s faithfulness despite seeming abandonment (cf. Jer. 29:10–14).

verses.text: He was raising Hadassah, that is Esther, the daughter of his uncle, for she had neither father nor mother. The young woman was beautiful of form and face, and when her parents died, Mordecai took her as his own daughter.
verses.comment: Esther’s orphanhood and adoption prefigure themes of divine election and spiritual adoption (cf. Rom. 8:15). Her dual names suggest a hidden identity, often interpreted spiritually as prefiguring the hiddenness of God’s chosen ones in the world.

verses.text: So when the king’s command and decree were proclaimed, and when many young women were gathered to the citadel of Susa under the care of Hegai, Esther was also taken to the king’s palace and put into the custody of Hegai, who was in charge of the women.
verses.comment: Esther’s selection is described passively, suggesting providence at work rather than personal ambition.

verses.text: The young woman pleased him and gained his favor, so he quickly provided her with beauty treatments and her portion of food, and assigned to her seven chosen young women from the king’s palace. He transferred her and her maids to the best place in the harem.
verses.comment: Esther finds favor, echoing Joseph’s favor in Egypt (cf. Gen. 39:4), hinting at God’s providential activity in exilic situations.

verses.text: Esther had not told her people or her family background, because Mordecai charged her not to reveal it.
verses.comment: The principle of prudent silence, obeying wise spiritual counsel, parallels other biblical examples of wisdom and obedience to spiritual oversight.

verses.text: Every day Mordecai walked before the courtyard of the harem to learn how Esther was and what was happening to her.
verses.comment: Mordecai’s daily concern for Esther shows the importance of intercessory care, anticipating the shepherding role later seen in church leadership.

verses.text: And when the time came for each young woman to go into King Ahasuerus, after twelve months under the regulations for the women—for the days of their beauty preparations were completed, six months with oil of myrrh and six months with spices and ointments for the women—
verses.comment: The ritual purification period parallels other biblical instances of preparation before entering a sacred or important presence (cf. Ex. 19:10–15).

verses.text: then this is how a young woman would go to the king: Whatever she asked for was given her to take from the harem to the king’s palace.
verses.comment: The permission to take whatever she desired shows the king’s generosity or perhaps test of discernment.

verses.text: In the evening she would go in, and in the morning she would return to the second harem, under the custody of Shaashgaz, the king’s eunuch, who was in charge of the concubines. She would not go to the king again unless the king delighted in her and summoned her by name.
verses.comment: Being called by name by the king represents special favor, pointing toward themes of election and being personally chosen (cf. Isa. 43:1).

verses.text: When it was Esther’s turn, the daughter of Abihail, Mordecai’s uncle, whom Mordecai had taken as his own daughter, to go in to the king, she asked for nothing except what Hegai, the king's eunuch, keeper of the women, advised. And Esther found favor in the sight of all who saw her.
verses.comment: Esther’s humble submission to guidance models perfect obedience, showing wisdom in taking counsel—prefiguring the Church’s trust in spiritual authority. Her universal favor foreshadows Mary’s 'full of grace' status (cf. Luke 1:28).

verses.text: So Esther was taken to King Ahasuerus, into his royal palace, in the tenth month, which is the month of Tebeth, in the seventh year of his reign.
verses.comment: The specificity of time underlines historical accuracy and reinforces the providential unfolding of God's plan.

verses.text: And the king loved Esther more than all the women, and she gained favor and grace before him above all the virgins, so he set the royal crown upon her head and made her queen instead of Vashti.
verses.comment: Esther’s elevation mirrors the biblical theme of God raising up the humble (cf. Luke 1:52). The crowning is reminiscent of spiritual anointing and divine favor.

verses.text: Then the king made a great feast for all his officials and servants, Esther’s feast; and he granted a holiday to the provinces and gave gifts as was the king’s custom.
verses.comment: This joyful celebration in honor of Esther hints at future religious feasts commemorating deliverance, winding forward to the institution of Purim.

verses.text: When the virgins were gathered together the second time, Mordecai was sitting at the king’s gate.
verses.comment: Mordecai’s position at the king’s gate precedes his later rise and involvement in the deliverance of Israel, illustrating how the righteous patiently wait and serve.

verses.text: Esther had not revealed her family or her people, just as Mordecai had instructed her; for Esther still did what Mordecai told her, just as when she was brought up by him.
verses.comment: Here obedience is emphasized—a model of honoring spiritual guidance, prefiguring the virtues of humility and submission to tradition.

verses.text: In those days, as Mordecai was sitting at the king’s gate, Bigthan and Teresh, two of the king’s eunuchs, who guarded the entrance, became angry and sought to lay hands on King Ahasuerus.
verses.comment: Mordecai’s vigilance is providential, reflecting God’s protection of His people through faithful servants.

verses.text: This became known to Mordecai, and he told it to Queen Esther, and Esther spoke to the king in Mordecai’s name.
verses.comment: Here we see the crucial role of mediation and intercession. Esther acts as an advocate, a model for how the chosen ones intercede with authority for the good of the community—anticipating New Testament themes of intercession (cf. 1 Tim. 2:1–2).

verses.text: When the affair was investigated and found to be true, the men were both hanged on the gallows; and it was recorded in the book of the chronicles in the presence of the king.
verses.comment: The written record of the salvation of the king through Mordecai prepares for future remembrance and vindication—foreshadowing the value placed on remembering acts of salvation and intercession.
